segments.text: If you're in business and you're a
leader trying to figure out where to
place your AI bets, most of the analysis
you read these days is kind of useless.
It's either too abstract. AI will
transform everything. It will automate
all things or it's too tactical. Here's
how to use Chad GPT for customer
service. What's missing is a strategic
middle layer, a clear picture of how AI
actually changes competitive dynamics
and what that means for where your
business is vulnerable and where it's
actually, ironically, protected. This is
what I'm focusing on in this video. The
key insight is that AI is not uniformly
intensifying competition everywhere.
It's actually bifurcating the economy.
And I don't think we talk about this
enough in digital spaces, contestable
markets, markets where output is easy to
compare and customers can switch easy.
AI is commoditizing the baseline there
and absolutely crushing middle tier
businesses. Whereas in physical markets,
markets that are dominated by local
relationship heavy dynamics, AI is
lowering overhead and it's not actually
increasing competitive pressure and so
prices and margins are rising in those
spaces. Your strategic position as a
business leader depends entirely on
where you sit in the economy and where
in the value chain your firm makes
money. And that should shape your AI
investment. So, by the end of this
video, I want you to have a sense of the
overall picture of AI implications for
the economy and for businesses and a
sense of how to diagnose where your
business sits and specific guidance on
AI investment based on your business's
position in the economy, which should
shape your durable advantage. If that
sounds like a mouthful, we're going to
get into it and explain how you can
actually analyze your own position, get
past the conventional wisdom, and come
to some useful conclusions around AI
investments. First, the standard story
about AI in business goes something like
this. Lean AI native startups are
growing quickly. They're proliferating,
and they will eat the giants unless the
giants accelerate because big companies
are slow. They're bureaucratic. They're
burdened by legacy systems, legacy
thinking. You've heard this story
before. Startups move fast. They adopt
new tools constantly. They build AI
native from day one. You've also heard
that story before. The disruptors will
win. The incumbents will fall. We've
seen this movie. The story isn't wrong
about everything, but it misses the
detailed shape of what's happening in
ways that help leaders make investment
decisions. And that's what I want to get
into here. First, the giants are not
nearly as vulnerable as the story might
suggest. Many of them have moes that AI
cannot effectively erode. And the
startups may not be quite as threatening
as advertised because the capabilities
that they are selling are often getting
cheaper by the month which is a problem
if your whole value proposition is the
capability and not the distribution.
Ironically the place where firms are
actually in trouble is in between
because the conventional wisdom is
looking just at the small firms and the
big firms and missing the entire middle
tier of the professional services and
software industries. Think the marketing
agency with 40 employees. The IT
consultancy that's been around for 15
years. The software development shop
that serves mid-market clients. The
design firm that built a reputation on
being reliable and improfessional over
the last couple of decades. Those firms
are getting squeezed from both
directions. from below by tiny teams
that are using AI to produce work that's
nearly indistinguishable from what a
mid-tier firm can get done and from
above by giants with distribution
advantages that the mid-tier firm cannot
match. They have no obvious escape
route. Now, let's jump over to a
different part of the economy. We've
looked at software for a second. I want
to look at the hardware side of things
briefly before we come back. If you were
in the atoms business, by which I mean
you move atoms around for a living,
maybe you're touching people's mouths
and you're a dentist, maybe you're an
HVAC technician, maybe you work in
plumbing, maybe you work in moving
people's homes, whatever it is, if
you're a plumber or accountant or a
specialty physician, net AI is helping
you. It is a huge tailwind for you
because it lowers your administrative
burdens. It makes you more efficient,
but it is not exposing you to the brutal
competition that's tearing its way
through the digital services and product
economies. And so to understand why
these patterns are emerging
simultaneously, why AI is not making
local services more competitive, but is
tearing into digital services, it's
important to get past the AI disrupts
everything story and get into the
specific mechanics of where pressure
intensifies and where it doesn't. And
that's going to lead us to an investment
strategy. So AI is collapsing the cost
of a specific kind of work. Cognitive
tasks that can be expressed in language.
If you are drafting, if you are
summarizing, if you are analyzing, if
you are researching, if you are coding
and planning and generating variations,
this is all tokenizable cognition. It's
thinking that can be captured as text.
And therefore, it is something that can
be handled by a language model. And the
cost of that work, I'm just going to be
honest, no one's surprised here, it's
falling towards zero. A first draft that
took a junior employee two hours now
takes 10 minutes at most. And research
that required a specialist can be done
with really good prompts in an hour or
so. The floor has risen dramatically.
Work that used to be hard to produce and
offer competitive advantage is now
trivially easy. But here's the point
where most AI commentator commentators
go off the rails. When something gets
cheaper, we typically use more of it,
not less. This is Jieven's paradox. It's
named after a 19th century economist who
noticed that the more efficient a steam
engine got, it didn't actually reduce
coal consumption. It exploded the usage
of steam engines. Efficiency made steam
power economical for brand new
applications. It removed a cost barrier
and demand just rushed in to fill that
cost barrier. The same thing is
happening with cognitive work. Firms
aren't producing less analysis because
AI makes analysis cheap. They're
producing far far more. More customer
segments each with detailed messaging,
more AB tests, more internal reports,
more first drafts to choose from. Now
you can get to your entire software
backlog. The volume of cognitive output
is exploding. It's not contracting. So
the first order effect is not AI
replaces cognitive workers. It is AI
enables vastly more cognitive work and
humans have to shift our tasks within
that expanded volume. And then the
question becomes which task do humans
shift to and what becomes a constraint
when the raw production of cognitive
work is essentially free. I'd like you
to think about what happens in a
business as having three layers. The
first layer is the tokenizable cognition
that I just talked about. Drafting,
analysis, coding, etc. This is the layer
where AI has made marginal cost
collapse. A firm can now produce
effectively unlimited quantities of this
work at near zero incremental cost. The
second layer is judgment and
accountability. Someone has to decide
which of the drafts look good. Someone
has to sign off on the analysis. Someone
has to own the outcome if the
recommendation turns out to be wrong.
This is not getting cheaper. This layer
requires human judgment and it requires
humans who are authorized to be
accountable. AI can generate the
options. It cannot own the
accountability for the decisions. The
final layer gets back to the atoms part
of the economy. It's physical execution.
Maybe that's installation. Maybe that's
repair. Maybe that's face-to-face
caregiving. No matter how good AI gets
at generating text, it cannot show up at
your house and fix your furnace. The
layer is constrained by the physical
world in ways that do not yield the
software improvements. And so what
happens when AI floods that first layer
with unparalleled abundance? Well, the
second and the third become binding
constraints in the software business
where you're not dealing with atoms as
much. It's just the second layer and
you're dealing with this incredible
crush of a bottleneck on judgment and
taste. In physical businesses, you have
both the second and the third layer in
play where you have judgment and taste
and also you have the need to provide
the physical service at a particular
time and place. But regardless of where
you sit, that three layer map is useful
because it gives you a sense of where
your competitive disadvantage lies. If
your firm mostly sells first layer work,
the drafting, the analysis, the code,
you got a big the work is becoming
commoditized. Your competitors can can
produce it for similar quality, often at
a lower cost. The thing you are selling
is no longer special. It's no longer
scarce. If your firm's value was always
in the second layer though, you're in a
much better spot. It was if it was
always in the relationships, if it was
always in the accountability, in the
good taste, you still need to produce
good first layer work, but now you can
produce it cheaper and you still depend
for value on that second layer, good
judgment and taste to compete. And of
course, if you're in the third layer,
you're in a really good spot because the
fundamental economics favor you at this
point. Now, let's get more precise about
who's in trouble and how competitive
positions are changing. Consider a
marketing agency with 50 employees for
the past 15 years. Let's say the firm's
made money by being professional. It's
reliable. It's competent. They're not
the cheapest, but they deliver really
good work. They deliver it on time, and
they've established client reputations.
What does this firm actually sell?
Mostly, it sells first layer work. It
sells plans. It sells campaigns. It
sells copy analysis. It sells strategy
decks. The partners did do some second
layer work. Uh they did some client
management. They did some
accountability. But the bulk of the
revenue is build to the cognitive
production of the staff that produces
all of these campaigns and so on. AI
changes this firm's competitive position
in multiple directions. Right from
below, a team of three people with good
AI tools can now produce as much work as
that 50 person agency produces. Now, is
it identical? No. But is it close enough
that clients start to wonder why they're
paying for 50 people? Yes, the tiny team
is faster, it's cheaper, and it's
increasingly competitive on quality.
They might not have the agency's
reputation, but they have a portfolio,
and they can price aggressively.
Meanwhile, look at a giant media
company. They they have holding
companies. They have platforms with
distribution modes. They can offer
endto-end turnkey service. They have
embedded offerings that lock clients
into ecosystems. They have advantages
that the 50 person company doesn't have
and can't hope to match. And so, the 50
person agency is really kind of stuck.
It can't match the cost structure of the
lean AI native competitors because it
has employees, it has offices, it has
overhead from a different era. And it
also can't match the distribution and
the stickiness the giants bring with
their ecosystem plays because it never
had those structural advantages in the
first place. That dynamic is now playing
out across the entire digital
professional services economy. software
consultancies, design firms, analytic
shops, current production companies,
research firms, any mid-tier player
whose value proposition was we produce
cognitive work is in danger. But
ironically, that same technology change
AI is actually good for the same size
firm in the atoms moving business. Let's
look at a plumbing company. The firm
sells third layer work mostly, right? A
human being shows up at your house. It
fixes the problem. The problem goes
away. Your pipes now work. AI helps this
firm. It can automate scheduling. It can
automate dispatch. It can automate
invoicing. And AI doesn't threaten the
firm in a way it threatens the marketing
agency because the service is not more
contestable. Contestability is really
the key concept here. A market is
contestable when buyers can easily
evaluate alternatives and switch very
effectively. But the plumbing company,
no matter how good AI is, is not going
to see a more contestable market.
whereas the marketing agency is because
it's really easy to switch marketing
agencies. I can switch for a marketing
agency in Hong Kong tomorrow. I cannot
switch for a plumber in Hong Kong. And
there's yet one more force working in
favor of the plumber. Bow's cost
disease. This is an economic observation
from the 1960s. As some sectors of the
economy get more productive, wages tend
to rise economywide, which means that
sectors that don't get more productive
become relatively more expensive. If the
classic example is orchestras, it still
takes the same number of musicians to
play a Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo
Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mo Mozart
Quartet as it did in 1790. But musicians
today get paid enormously more because
they could otherwise go and work in
industries where productivity has
increased. AI is making parts of the
economy dramatically more productive.
That is going to pull up wages
everywhere and anything that can't be
made productive by AI is going to become
relatively more expensive. This is a
counterintuitive claim. Most people are
going to tell you that you're going to
see wages hit the wall, that there's
going to be massive unemployment, etc.
But one of the thing we don't discuss is
that that will only happen if and when
AI is able to get into the second and
third layers that I've been talking
about. If AI gets into the judgment and
taste layer, if AI gets into physical
atoms and touching spaces. Now, I know
that we've made investments in robotics.
There's entire startups that are going
after that space. That breakthrough is
not here yet. I think we are much more
likely to see breakthroughs in factories
than we are to see breakthroughs in home
services in the near term. But by and
large, we aren't seeing the kind of
generalpurpose technology unlock for
robotics yet in the way that we have for
language and text. And we aren't seeing
the kind of general purpose unlock on
judgment and taste in cognitive services
that we have seen for the production and
drafting of work. So drafting code is
easy. It still takes a good senior
engineer to architect the system to
ensure it actually works correctly. If
you put all this together, you get a
bifurcated economy, a barbell economy.
On the one end, you have digital and
contestable markets where AI is
commoditizing the baseline and
intensifying competition. In those
markets, the long tale of mediocre
producers is going to die quickly.
Competition consolidates around firms
that either have distribution modes or
firms with incredible efficiency. Think
small AI native teams. The middle is
going to get crushed between those two
ends. On the other side, you have
physical local relationship heavy
markets where AI lowers the overhead
through efficiencies in back office
automation, but doesn't actually
increase the contestability of the
market. And in those markets, the
longtail survives and frankly often
thrives. So given all of this, here's
how to think about AI investments
depending on where you sit. If you're a
mid-tier firm in a contestable digital
market, think marketing, software
services, design, content, analytics,
you've got two viable paths. And yes,
you do have a death trap. Path one is to
get radically lean. You need to cut your
headcount. You have to cut overhead. You
have to rebuild around a small core team
that uses AI to produce at the level
your current staff produces. You're
racing against threeperson startups, and
you need to act like it. Path two is you
got to move up the stack. You stop
selling first layer cognitive production
and you start leaning really heavily
into second layer judgment,
accountability, quality. This means
changing what you charge for, right? You
can't ch charge for deliverables in the
same way you're charging for the quality
of the output that you're actually
selling. And so your AI investments need
to support that shift. They need to
support the tools that help your senior
people to do more high judgment work
well. And that's different from
investing in tools that help junior
people produce more drafts. Now, the
death trap is investing in AI to make
your current model more efficient. If
your model is 50 people producing
cognitive work and you make that 20%
more efficient with AI, it's probably
not enough to compete with the super
lean players that are three people
strong. You're just dying slower. Let's
switch over. If you're a firm in a
physical local relationship heavy
market, let's say you're in the trades,
you're in dentistry, your AI investments
should actually focus really heavily on
back office, right? overhead reduction
and customer experience are not going to
be as important, ironically, and instead
investing in basic stuff like
scheduling, dispatch optimization,
automating customer communications,
getting quotes out to every customer,
invoicing and collections. This does
improve the customer experience in the
sense that it makes it more predictable,
every single call gets answered, etc.
But all it really does is it makes your
back office operation more turnkey so
that you can focus on delivering in the
market in physical spaces where you
actually compete. AI can't do that part.
And so in that world, you should
actually be aware of vendors that sell
transformation when what you're really
looking for is just those basic
efficiency plays. Now, if you're
building or investing in AI native
startups, you have a different position
to play. You have to understand and
think all the time about the fact that
pure cognitive production is a
depreciating asset. If your startup's
value proposition is we use AI to
produce X cheaper and faster, you're in
the commodity business. Every other AI
native startup can make the same claim.
Your margins will compress as the
underlying models keep getting cheaper.
This can still be a good business if you
have distribution, if you're embedded in
workflows, if you have a platform, if
switching costs are high, but cognitive
production is not a moat. And so the
startups that will sustain value here
are those that own bottlenecks in the
second layer. Run toward compliance. Run
toward audit infrastructure. Run toward
really solid human in the loop review
systems as a part of what you offer. Run
toward liability and accountability
wrappers around agents. Run toward
workflow orchestration that embeds you
in how your clients operate. These are
harder to build than AI that makes X,
but they're much more defensible in ways
that pure production of tokens is not
going to be defensible long term. Last
but not least, let's say you're a giant
with a real distribution moat for you.
AI is a huge upside opportunity. The
moat protects you, right? Let's just be
honest. Embedded client relationships,
bundled offerings, platform status,
brand recognition, none of these are
automatically eroded by AI. If anything,
they become more valuable because they
become tokens of authenticity as the
production layer commoditizes. And
distribution is going to become a more
and more scarce resource. And guess
what? You're sitting on it. You got
distribution. But your risk is internal
and talentled. The threat is not that
startups will eat you. It's that they
will hire away your best people because
startups can move faster and offer more
upside to the individual employee. The
threat is really that you will not be
able to change how you operate fast
enough and startups will start to eat
away the edges of the empire that you've
created in ways that ultimately it's the
death by a thousand cuts risk that you
have to face and it starts as an
internal talent threat. And so your AI
investment should be coupled with
genuine operational change because you
are investing in your teams. You're
convincing your teams that they are in
the right place, that you care about
them, they have an AI native future here
in this larger business, and that you're
going to give them the tools that they
need to build amazing things inside this
larger enterprise. There is an internal
innovation challenge for large companies
that I think we often overlook and firms
that lose long-term. When you think
about the slow death of Kmart in the US
and other big department stores, those
are firms that ultimately lost the
ability to deliver extraordinary service
to their customers and they were just
out competed by firms that were able to
do the same thing efficiently over time.
And that, by the way, is an example of a
firm that got out competed even though
it had advantages in that third layer
physical space. You had to go to a store
to buy furniture in the old days, right?
I know it's hard to believe for the
young people, but it's true. And Walmart
out competed them because Walmart was
able to deliver on the core promise of
putting inventory where the customer
could get it at more affordable prices
in a wider array of places and
ultimately built out the brand. And so I
know I've emphasized the advantages big
firms have and we and you do, right? You
have strong advantages across the board,
especially around distribution, but that
doesn't make you immune to the
competitive environment threat that AI
is generating. Think of AI as increasing
the speed of all of the ankle biters in
your space, all of the small firms that
are nibbling at the business. And your
job is to invest on your internal talent
side enough that you can encourage
innovation within your larger
departments at a pace that allows you to
match the threats of those ankle biters
and defend the space that your business
currently occupies reliably and even
continue to grow. The bottom line here
is that AI, this is for everybody. AI is
not uniformly intensifying competition.
It's actually reshaping which markets
are contestable and which are not, which
parts of the value chain are scarce and
which are abundant. And so your
strategic position, where you choose to
invest, it really depends on having a
very cleareyed assessment of where you
sit in this reshaped 2026 economic
landscape. If you're in the middle tier
of a contestable digital market, you're
an endangered species. You have to
choose a direction. You got to get get
differentiated or you got to get lean.
Staying in the middle is not a strategy
that works. If you're in a physical
local relationship heavy market, you're
more protected. AI becomes an
opportunity to get more efficient, but
you shouldn't mistake efficiency tools
for the kind of strategic transformation
that lots of people are trying to sell
you because there's no point in becoming
AI transformed entirely if AI is not
going to actually change what you
deliver and you're a plumber. Like, you
got to just do the plumbing. If you're
building or funding AI native startups,
you've got to run as fast as possible
toward distribution advantage and toward
those second level bottlenecks where
humans need to exercise good judgment
because if you're just producing
something that depends on tokens, you're
you're in a losing position long term.
And finally, if you're a giant, the
opportunity is real, but the risk of
squandering it is real, too. AI doesn't
directly threaten your moat, but it
strengthens your ankle biter competitors
and it requires you to change how you
work so that you can retain talent and
keep your competitive advantage long
term. So this bifurcated economy is
going to shape where all of us work in
2026. You already are standing in this
economy. The question is, how are you
shaping your AI investments to make
sense of where your unique position is?
I'd love to hear what you think in the
comments. Cheers.
